title: How to Build a Desktop Catapult

steps.headline: Buy the materials needed for the project.
steps.description: See the complete list under Things You'll Need, later in the article. All the components for this project cost less than $15 (US), and there was no problem finding them.

steps.headline: Assemble your tools on a convenient workbench or other suitable location.
steps.description:
The following were used in this assembly:
Circular saw
Battery and electric drills with bits
Sander
Hot glue gun
Measuring tape
Hammer
Utility knife

steps.headline: Cut out the following required pieces.
steps.description:
You will need:
1 piece 3/4 plywood, 9X16 inches
2- 1/2 inch diameter dowels, 12 inches (30.5 cm) long
2- 1/2 inch diameter dowels, 18 inches (45.7 cm) long
4- 1/4 inch diameter dowels, 18 inches (45.7 cm) long
2- 1/4 inch diameter dowels, 16 inches (40.6 cm) long
2- 3/8 inch diameter dowels, 7 inches (17.8 cm) long
3- 3/8 inch diameter dowels, 18 inches (45.7 cm) long
various spacer blocks cut from the dowels listed above
various lengths of twine to lash dowels together while assembling. These lashings give the catapult its structural soundness.

steps.headline: Lay out plywood for holes required for the frame, as shown in photo.
steps.description: Mark the board lengthwise at 1 inch (2.5 cm) and 9 inches (22.9 cm) with a framing square or rule, then mark the center line, from which you measure out 3 inches (7.6 cm) either way for the holes.

steps.headline: Drill holes with a ⁄32 inch (1.2 cm) bit to install uprights at the 9 inch (22.9 cm) mark.
steps.description: These holes are drilled perpendicular to the board.

steps.headline: Drill holes with the ⁄32 inch (1.2 cm) bit at the one inch marks at a 50 degree angle to the board.
Drill one hole with a ⁄16 inch (0.8 cm) bit in each 18 inch (45.7 cm) by ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) dowel at 6 inches (15.2 cm) and 1 inch (2.5 cm) from one end.
steps.description: These are the holes for the cross beams to fit into.

steps.headline: Drive the 18 inch (45.7 cm) by ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) dowels into the holes on the 9 inch (22.9 cm) marks.
steps.description: Drive the 12 inch (30.5 cm) by ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) dowels into the holes at the one inch marks, they should intersect the vertical dowels at their tops. Some carpenter's wood glue applied to the ends of these dowels will help hold them securely in place.

steps.headline: Glue the dowels together where they meet at the top, then lash them with twine for support.
steps.description: Hot melt wood glue will save a lot of time on this step, and a dab of glue will help secure the lashing twine when it is knotted.

steps.headline: 'Taper the ends of the ⁄8 inch (1.0 cm) by 7 inch (17.8 cm) dowels with sandpaper so they fit snugly into the two holes at the top of the upright ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) dowels, then spread the uprights to fit them in.
steps.description: If these are not snug enough, glue them in place.

steps.headline: Lash the ⁄4 inch (0.6 cm) by 18 inch (45.7 cm) dowels to the upright ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) dowels with twine, then hot glue the twine to prevent it from slipping.
Assemble the two ⁄8 inch (1.0 cm) by 18 inch (45.7 cm) dowels together, parallel, with space blocks between them cut from the same material.
steps.description: The spaces should be located so that the pivot point is an open space about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) wide, which will be the location for it to be placed on the pivot beam. Leave another space about 1 ⁄2 inches (3.8 cm) long at the top end of this assembly (the launch arm). This is where the cup, or projectile holder will fit.

steps.headline: Spread the uprights sufficiently to install the launch arm, then replace the cross arms, gluing them into position.
Carve a suitable "cup", or projectile holder from your scrap of 2X4 lumber, rough shaping it with a circular saw, then rotary rasps, and finally a sanding disk or sandpaper.
steps.description: This can be carved by hand if you prefer, since it will be a fairly small piece of wood to hold securely while using your power tools for carving.

steps.headline: Lash the projectile cup into the notch at the end of the launch arms using the twine.
steps.description: You will want to be certain to lash this tightly and glue the lashings in place to avoid accidentally launching the complete cup when you fire the catapult.

steps.headline: Glue or lash guide pieces for the travel of the launch arm between the two cross beams, and from the base diagonally up the path of travel of your arm.
steps.description: These will keep the launch arm assembly in line while it swings during launch. If the arm and pivot bar are tight enough to keep the assembly in alignment, these pieces can be left off.

steps.headline: Fasten a spring at the bottom of the launch arm to a point on the opposite side of the base, using twine.
steps.description: Adjust the tension so that the launch arm can be drawn back to a horizontal position for loading and firing. Using a stronger spring will make your catapult more powerful, but this is not always desirable, since it causes a lot of stress on the moving components. Most hardware stores have an assortment of various springs, so you may need to experiment a bit here to find one that works for you.

steps.headline: Trim any loose strings, check all glue joints, and you should be ready to fire.
steps.description: Pull back the launch arm and release it from various draws to determine the range and power you are looking for. If none of the parts become loose or lose tension, you can launch similar size and weight projectiles with remarkable consistency using this device.

text:
Buy the materials needed for the project. See the complete list under Things You'll Need, later in the article. All the components for this project cost less than $15 (US), and there was no problem finding them. Assemble your tools on a convenient workbench or other suitable location. The following were used in this assembly:
Circular saw
Battery and electric drills with bits
Sander
Hot glue gun
Measuring tape
Hammer
Utility knife Cut out the following required pieces. You will need:
1 piece 3/4 plywood, 9X16 inches
2- 1/2 inch diameter dowels, 12 inches (30.5 cm) long
2- 1/2 inch diameter dowels, 18 inches (45.7 cm) long
4- 1/4 inch diameter dowels, 18 inches (45.7 cm) long
2- 1/4 inch diameter dowels, 16 inches (40.6 cm) long
2- 3/8 inch diameter dowels, 7 inches (17.8 cm) long
3- 3/8 inch diameter dowels, 18 inches (45.7 cm) long
various spacer blocks cut from the dowels listed above
various lengths of twine to lash dowels together while assembling. These lashings give the catapult its structural soundness. Lay out plywood for holes required for the frame, as shown in photo. Mark the board lengthwise at 1 inch (2.5 cm) and 9 inches (22.9 cm) with a framing square or rule, then mark the center line, from which you measure out 3 inches (7.6 cm) either way for the holes. Drill holes with a ⁄32 inch (1.2 cm) bit to install uprights at the 9 inch (22.9 cm) mark. These holes are drilled perpendicular to the board. Drill holes with the ⁄32 inch (1.2 cm) bit at the one inch marks at a 50 degree angle to the board.  Drill one hole with a ⁄16 inch (0.8 cm) bit in each 18 inch (45.7 cm) by ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) dowel at 6 inches (15.2 cm) and 1 inch (2.5 cm) from one end. These are the holes for the cross beams to fit into. Drive the 18 inch (45.7 cm) by ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) dowels into the holes on the 9 inch (22.9 cm) marks. Drive the 12 inch (30.5 cm) by ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) dowels into the holes at the one inch marks, they should intersect the vertical dowels at their tops. Some carpenter's wood glue applied to the ends of these dowels will help hold them securely in place. Glue the dowels together where they meet at the top, then lash them with twine for support. Hot melt wood glue will save a lot of time on this step, and a dab of glue will help secure the lashing twine when it is knotted. 'Taper the ends of the ⁄8 inch (1.0 cm) by 7 inch (17.8 cm) dowels with sandpaper so they fit snugly into the two holes at the top of the upright ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) dowels, then spread the uprights to fit them in. If these are not snug enough, glue them in place. Lash the ⁄4 inch (0.6 cm) by 18 inch (45.7 cm) dowels to the upright ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) dowels with twine, then hot glue the twine to prevent it from slipping.  Assemble the two ⁄8 inch (1.0 cm) by 18 inch (45.7 cm) dowels together, parallel, with space blocks between them cut from the same material. The spaces should be located so that the pivot point is an open space about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) wide, which will be the location for it to be placed on the pivot beam. Leave another space about 1 ⁄2 inches (3.8 cm) long at the top end of this assembly (the launch arm). This is where the cup, or projectile holder will fit. Spread the uprights sufficiently to install the launch arm, then replace the cross arms, gluing them into position.  Carve a suitable "cup", or projectile holder from your scrap of 2X4 lumber, rough shaping it with a circular saw, then rotary rasps, and finally a sanding disk or sandpaper. This can be carved by hand if you prefer, since it will be a fairly small piece of wood to hold securely while using your power tools for carving. Lash the projectile cup into the notch at the end of the launch arms using the twine. You will want to be certain to lash this tightly and glue the lashings in place to avoid accidentally launching the complete cup when you fire the catapult. Glue or lash guide pieces for the travel of the launch arm between the two cross beams, and from the base diagonally up the path of travel of your arm. These will keep the launch arm assembly in line while it swings during launch. If the arm and pivot bar are tight enough to keep the assembly in alignment, these pieces can be left off. Fasten a spring at the bottom of the launch arm to a point on the opposite side of the base, using twine. Adjust the tension so that the launch arm can be drawn back to a horizontal position for loading and firing. Using a stronger spring will make your catapult more powerful, but this is not always desirable, since it causes a lot of stress on the moving components. Most hardware stores have an assortment of various springs, so you may need to experiment a bit here to find one that works for you. Trim any loose strings, check all glue joints, and you should be ready to fire. Pull back the launch arm and release it from various draws to determine the range and power you are looking for. If none of the parts become loose or lose tension, you can launch similar size and weight projectiles with remarkable consistency using this device. Finished.
